information:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: A man wins, continuing the pattern from 2023 and 2024
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: One of the male finalists wins the Outstanding Chef award, maintaining the recent two-year trend of male winners despite a female finalist being in contention.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Cassie Piuma wins the Outstanding Chef award, breaking the two-year streak of male winners and becoming the fifth woman in the last eleven years to win this national award.
forecast.rationale:
The historical base rate shows women have won 40% (4 out of 10) of Outstanding Chef awards in the last decade, establishing a reasonably strong precedent. However, the recent trend shows consecutive male winners in 2023 and 2024, even after the James Beard Foundation's 2020 equity initiative.

The equity initiative has demonstrably affected regional awards, with female winners jumping from 30% to 55% in the Best Chef categories. This suggests the Foundation is successfully implementing structural changes toward inclusivity. However, the Outstanding Chef national award appears less affected - continuing to go to men in recent years despite these broader institutional changes.

Cassie Piuma's finalist status is crucial - a woman must be a finalist to win, and she is. However, we lack information about the strength and number of other finalists, which introduces uncertainty.

My forecast is not higher because: (1) the recent trend strongly favors male winners in this specific category, (2) momentum from two consecutive male winners suggests either continued patterns or that recent male candidates have been exceptionally strong, and (3) the national Outstanding Chef award has proven more resistant to equity initiative effects than regional categories.

My forecast is not lower because: (1) the 40% historical base rate is substantial, (2) equity initiatives are showing real institutional effects, even if delayed for this category, (3) a qualified female finalist exists, and (4) after two male winners, there may be heightened awareness about representation.

I would update higher if: information emerged about Piuma being a particularly strong favorite, or if judges indicated emphasis on equity considerations for this cycle. I would update lower if: multiple strong male finalists were identified, or if industry consensus pointed strongly toward a male winner.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will a woman win the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef?

Question background:
[Here Are the 2025 James Beard Awards Restaurant, Chef, and Media Award Finalists](https://www.eater.com/24398769/2025-james-beard-awards-restaurant-chef-finalists)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if a woman wins the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef.




Your research assistant's report says:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

Today is 2025-05-27.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
